list_definition.definition: a long (narrow) piece of leather, cloth etc worn round the waist
a similar object used to set wheels in motion

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The belt of the vacuum cleaner needs replacing.

list_definition.definition: to strike (with or without a belt)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He belted the ball as hard as he could.

list_ex_of_english: Devices like the hopper boy, conveyors, lifts, and leather belting reappeared as parts of a more general mass production over the following century.
Thermally softened continental extensional zones (arcs and rifts) as precursors to thickened orogenic belts.
Within fluvial systems, channel belts and floodplains (sites of deposition of both clastic and phytogenic material) environments coexisted.
Varying relative sea-level mainly controlled the broad types of facies belts that developed.
The interfluve surface shows the presence of many abandoned channel belts which receive no sediment or water from any major river system.
The variation in the nature of these belts is due almost entirely to the amount of surface moisture, the greater the amount of moisture the denser the undergrowth.
As these specialised machines were normally both stationary and operated inside buildings, prime movers could supply power via shafting or belts.
Occasionally, these are of very limited extent, but sometimes stretch in narrow belts of 50-200 yards in width for several miles.
